description.text: Retro Things. HAVE FUN RE-LIVING YOUR CHILDHOOD! made in TINKERCAD

4 bladed prop for a small outboard gasoline engine or trolling motor.  Counter rotation (CCW).  Print at least 25% infill in ABS.  Cant remember shaft size but im pretty sure its .38 inches.  Was used for a weed whacker outboard motor and worked pretty well (reason for weird shaft diameter).

This was just a silly idea I had while working on the bobblehead cat. It sort of snowballed out of control from there. It isn't very good in the snow anymore.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXrs8lSHalY

Print one of everything except the chin blasters (you need two), the bodies and the heads. The difference between the regular and LD bodies is the LD version has less detail in... whatever you'd call the protrusions down the sides (greebles?), as my printer didn't bother printing them.
If you don't mind the seam, print the head and chin seperately and snap them together with the pins. I've added a one-piece head that should be printable without support, but it puts the "face" on top so the finish might not look so great, depending on how much stepping you get.
Everything but the blasters can be printed raftless. I'd recommend turning your feedrate way down for the chin, pins and blasters.
The chin blasters crack the sockets, but they haven't fallen out so I figure its fine.
As with the cat, you can use anything from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17725 as the neck, but bobblehead action seems to be limited by head weight and ground clearance so I went with a short snake pin. The blend file is there if anyone wants to do the undercarriage and proper legs for it.

author: Philf

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:368375 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=368375
its a chicken

This was designed specifically for one of my photo customers who has a degenerative condition, Late Onset Taye-Sachs disease.  He experiences muscle fatigue and problems with grip and steadiness, so he uses a smaller point-and-shoot camera with a table-top tripod for a hand-grip.  
The problems are multi-fold.  One is that the tripod has to be removed every time he changes his batteries, or when he puts the camera away, and he disassembles the whole setup for storage and transport.  Two is that when he does this, it wears out the 1/4-20 tripod mount in the camera, which is plastic.
Instead of ordering a steady supply of new tripod mounts, which would only solve one problem, we agreed on an offset platform so we could move the tripod mount towards the center of the lens axis, and allow the battery door to open and close with ease.  The two-fingered offset on one side allows a 1/4-20 bolt to lock down into the camera, with the intention of it no longer being removed regularly.  We agreed to modify the camera a little so it could support a second mount on the far side, so I disassembled and bored out the hole for the body panels.
The center hole supports a standard 1/4-20 nut to interface with whatever you connect the camera to.  This should prove much more reliable than any type of plastic could.
Don stopped by the shop today and picked it up, and was very pleased with the results.  I'm posting it just because it's my first serious design project, and I'm pleased too.  We put a Joby Gorillapod quick-release plate on the bottom of it, locked up nice and tight, and set him up with a monopod with a Joby ballhead, and a Gorillapod SLR Zoom with the same.  Now he has one plate mounted full-time, and two methods to support it.  Testing will tell if it flies long-term, and we can just print another one!

Print with thicker walls, and a tighter infill.  The little tiny holes are not for cosmetic purposes, but make the shape much more rigid structurally.  Since they qualify as external areas of the shape, they get built up nice and fat, like little columns of awesome.  However, the unit will print sort of sporadically, unless there's a setting for outside->in printing method.  My final print had some gaps in the top surface, but that's my machine getting fine-tuned still. 
Try it if you like!  This was designed for a Canon Powershot SX110/120, but might work fine for other models.

title: WD MyBook Live Duo - Cooling Stand

description.text:
Its summer down here in Australia, and this summer its hot, really hot. I keep getting status reports from my WD MyBook Live Duo that it is overheating. So I designed and printed this cooling stand to improve its passive airflow circulation - so far so good.
The stand will fit any WD Duo/Raid external storage device, like my MyBook Studio 4T.
This cooling stand was designed using an ASIC solid in Shark FX (sfx file included) so will behave well with Makerware, ReplicatorG and skeinforge.
UPDATE: Seems to be doing the job, I haven't heard a peep out of my MBL over the past few days and it been over 30 degrees c.

I printed this with silver PLA filament with 2 shells, 15% infill and 0.2 mm layer height with the skin module activated in Skeinforge/ReplicatorG so that the outside surface had a 0.1 mm finish. 
The plate includes my snap off ear raft print aids, to increase the surface area of the narrow edge to prevent them from breaking loose during printing.

The Rancilio Rocky is a very popular coffee grinder but the doser is terrible. This is a doser that delivers a single shot cleanly into the portafilter.

The photograph shows the Rancilio doser model for which this replacement is intended. The STL's will provide a new doser bowl and plunger and lid. Once printed the bowl is easily attached with the existing Rancilio hardware fittings; firm as a rock (!). You can find a video of it at work at http://youtu.be/0S_ugKZQhtQ. For those interested in the timer underneath the grinder, the PDF file includes the circuit schematic and sourcing details. UPDATE 2013.04 There are now STL's for dual color printing so you can have a different colored "tell" on the chute. If you have printed the main part in black, it can be very difficult to see whether you already have a dose ground in the hopper. There is now an inset that you can print in another color - I use white - which makes it less likely you will "double grind" by mistake. The wide base flange you just cut off with scissors; stops all warping!

comments.text: I don't even have a Rocky, but as someone who has used one, I applaud your effort in improving the bad design it uses.

This is a duct for a vertically-mounted 50mm squirrel-cage blower fan. It snaps directly onto the blower. I'm using it for my modified 3DR Simple 3D printer, but it is pretty generic and could be used for just about anything that needs such a part. It works great for cooling PLA. Some compatible parts:
  • 24v 50mm Squirrel-Cage Blower Fan
  • 12v 50mm Squirrel-Cage Blower Fan
    • EDIT: I've improved this model by increasing the size of the nozzle. In the previous version of the duct, the nozzle was too small, seriously restricting airflow. The newer models have the word Blower- in front of the files. I've left the old ones intact for historical reasons.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder / Handle

description.text: This spool holder improves rigidity, holds spools of all sizes and is a great handle to pickup your bot. I've moved my designs over to YouMagine.com all updates for this design will be found there. https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-simple-metal-spool-holder-handle A handle and spool holder that clamps on to both 12mm rods to add rigidity to your Printrbot Simple Metal. This design fits right off the print bed and doesn't need support. Print this with 35% infill or higher for strength. This design is meant to echo the aesthetic style of the simple metal, it is designed to not interfere with any working parts, its large but very sturdy. Remixes encouraged - Sketchup file is included on YouMagine Website.

Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner
Just like the big wind turbines...

You will need some super glue and some basic plastic soldering skills.
Glue tower pieces together.  Top and bottom may need a little shaving.
Heat up blade pins with a lighter (do not set it on fire!) and press them into the three blade sockets on the hub.
With tin snips cut a trim nail down to around 1" including the head.
Heat up the head of the nail with a lighter.  When hot, press it into the bottom hole on the hub and sort of carve out a little cavity for the head to sit in.
While plastic is still malleable press in on the plastic around the nail neck to keep the nail head inside the hub.  Make sure the hub spins freely on the nail.
Heat up other side of the nail and place it into the forward hole on the nacelle.  Hold steady until plastic cools.
Heat up the ends of the tower to place in bottom of hub and base.
Enjoy.

It was time to rebuild the Carb in my project car and decided that it would be nice to have a level platform to work on it.  You can rest the carb on its baseplate or flip the stand over and rest it on the air cleaner flange to gain access to the underside.  
I had seen products like this on Jegs and Summit and decided to make my own version.  Intake manifold spacing is for a Holley 4150 carb but should work for most V8 intakes (5.125" x 5.625") and a air cleaner flange diameter of 5".  Again, this should be pretty standard but you should double check before you print.  
Enjoy!

Make sure to grab (4) 3 1/2" long, 1/4-20 bolts and nuts for the base plate.  Feed the bolt up through each leg and tighten with a nut.  You may need to add washers under the nut to give you clearance for your throttle linkages.

description.text:
Confirmed to fit on both X and Y axis of a Thing-O-Matic 3D printer. HOLE HEIGHT NOT COMPATIBLE WITH ANY OF THE ANCESTORS OF THIS DESIGN.
  • Lowered the thickness to not interfere with bolts on the X axis.
  • Reduced side thickness to not interfere with X axis walls.
    • M4 tensoner screw
    • Version 2- Cleaned the file up and added slightly more material to improve the strength of the part.

• Print out object at a high infill (i used 60%)
  • Ensure hole sizes are correct, drilling any holes if required
  • Check that a M4 Bolt fits correctly in the slot
  • Tape the any surfaces in contact with motor sliding with kapton tape to reduce friction
  • Once ensuring that the part does fit, drill a 4mm hole where the Tensoner bolt meets the wall
  • Screw motor in, just tight enough that it still moves by hand
  • Use the tensoner bolt to tension the belt. Remember that the tigher it the belt the the more the stepper motor needs to work.

These are brackets for clipping an empty "Nutella & Go!" snack container to 1515 aluminum extrusions (Kossel Clear, etc.), for use as a tool holder.  These containers have two compartments, one shorter than the other, and are fairly sturdy considering their disposable nature.  (Also: delicious!)  
Unlike the fully-printed tool holder I linked to as an inspiration, these will fit the "giant" size Elmer's glue sticks (my bed adhesion aid of choice).

You will need to print two clips per container.  Some clean-up of the inside of the thin slots may be needed.  
To install, snip off the lip of the container at the two corners.  Slide the clips on at those points, then swivel them towards the back side of the container to lock them into place.  
The label peels off of the container easily, I just left it in place for the photo to help identify the product I'm referring to.

This is a simple thing that slips over the end of the upper lever arm of a nail clipper, to give you a better grip.  At least for me, it keeps my thumb from sliding down the lever arm, so it is easier to clip my finger nails. I was surprised at how much difference it made..
The OpenSCAD file is entirely parametric, but I think most nail clippers can be accommodated by changing just two input parameters, as explained in the OpenSCAD file.
The sketch (pdf file) shows at least most of the parameters and variables, and a very rough sketch of the thing. It's a scan of the un-cleaned-up sketch I used during the final design stage.

I use it on a Groovemount-compatible plate to hold my J-head hotend in. Instructions:
  • Adjust couplingdiam in SCAD if necessary and create STL file.
  • Print.
  • Ideally use tapping kit to tap threads into the main hole. If you don't have a tapping kit, it is possible to self-tap if you are careful.
  • Mount with M3 bolts or similar sized SAE bolts.

title: Tripod mount for Nokia N900 smartphone

description.text:
A very simple no-frills tripod mount for the Nokia N900 phone.  
No fancy lock-in-place features, but I'm sure you could add a rubber band to make non-landscape orientation possible. Contains a hole for the common 1/4" tripod mount thread. The "default" version has 3 mm thick walls and base plate; the "2mm" files have (surprisingly) 2 mm walls.  
See the "Instructions" tab for comments on how a test printout (of the default version) turned out.

I've printed out a single copy of the "default" version on a miniFactory (v2.0, I believe) printer at the local library. At their semi-standard settings (PLA, 0.2 mm layers, 10% infill, 3 surface layers, etc.), printing took around 7 hours. As you can possibly see from the photos, despite a heated print platform and there not being all that much plastic in the design, the left side (camera side) started to warp and curl off the print bed approximately when the base plate was finished. Could be a defect in the design, or a miscalibrated printer, or something else. Your mileage may vary. The right side did not detach, and the print finished successfully -- possibly helped by a bit of tape to hold the other side down. The end result is slightly wonky, but certainly functional. The N900 fits very snugly in its slot, with basically no wiggle room at all. You might consider making it slightly larger, and then adding (e.g. cardboard) padding to compensate. Theoretically speaking -- in the model -- the slot is supposed to be 1 mm larger than the N900, based on official dimensions and local measurements. The hole for the tripod screw is also quite tight. The normal screw in the quick-release plate of my (cheap) tripod is definitely not long enough to go through the 3 mm plate, so I use a ($1.50, from eBay) "tripod screw to camera hot shoe adapter" (you can see it in the photo) as a longer screw and a corresponding bolt. The 2 mm version I haven't tried at all.

title: Parametric R/C Heli/Quadcopter Training Gear Hub

description.text: This print allows you to make your own R/C Heli/Quadcopter training gear, with the similar levels of accuracy and build characteristics as store-bought training gear. As it's parametric, you can define the number of arm sockets as well as your choice of rod diameter. Additional cutouts are done to minimize the weight of the hub. Hopefully this will give you optimum flexibility in printing one with the correct size/arm count for your bird. The default settings in the .SCAD and exported STL are for a 200-size heli, using 3mm carbon fiber rods as the arms. UPDATE: Download the .STL file for a pre-generated hub set for 45mm diameter and 3mm rods. This .STL has additional fillets to strengthen the hub at its weakest points, and chamfers to ease insertion of the rods.

Materials you'll need, besides this print:
  • 1) Rods for the landing gear. Carbon fiber rods are highly recommended for their shock-absorbing properties. Number of rods depends on the number of arms you set. Diameter depends on the type of bird you have.
  • 2) CA glue - apply some onto the rod before sticking it into the hub.
  • 3) Ping pong balls, whiffle balls, sponge balls, any round, smooth sphere to stab onto the end of your rod
  • 4) Cable ties to attach to your R/C heli.
    • Print instructions/tips:
  • 1) Use ABS. PLA will probably work but might be too brittle for R/C heli usage. IMPLA might work, though I've never tried that.
  • 2) The hub is printed upside down. No support material is needed.
  • 3) Specify a decent plugwall width, or risk rods snapping the printed arms off in a hard landing.
  • 4) If you're gonna use carbon fiber rod (or tube), go for a relatively thin diameter enough to hold up your heli, but pliant enough to absorb shock from bad landings. 3mm rod for my 200-size heli seems to work.

author: CuadraL

title: RepRap Touch TFT LCD (mini pronterface style)

description.header: This project is no longer supported !
This project is out of date (2012) Is not supported in the current Marlin Firmware !
description.text:
This is a Touch TFT LCD project for my reprappro Mendel. This LCD works in standalone mode, it has an internal PICASO microcontroller.
The entire Graphics interface is not managed by Marlin Firmware but the PICASO micro.
My PICASO firmware send commands through the GCODE protocol to RepRap main board.
The communication is done by a second serial port.

This is a firmware to control the RepRap 3D printers with a Touch TFT LCD. It is designed around the 4D-Systems uLCD-32PT LCD model. Features:

  • Work in standalone mode, no PC is required

  • Intuitive Touch Interface, no external button is required

  • Graphical interface 'Pronterface' style

  • Show SD card file content, print the selected file,Pause/Resume.

  • Move X,Y,Z axis with a touch

  • Show Temperature and Target Temp up to two Extruder

  • Extrude/Reverse Filament functionality (Settings mm and mm/min)

  • Set HotEnd Target Temp

  • Set Bed Target Temp

  • Zprobe and Z offset functionality

  • Wav Sound to notify the end of print

  • Only two pin for communication (TX1,RX1) ,perfect for Melzi/Sanguino board

many users are complaining about to Ramp support..
I would like to clarify some things:
the project was designed around the reprappro Mendel version, so I developed the changes in the Marlin reprappro branch.
I started working at 4D Display support in original Marlin, but I got bad results as first attempts (the original Marlin has very fast developed and many things have changed lately).
I need time to align the project to the original Marlin, code contributions are welcome !
To resolve this problem there are two ways:
1) Add support for Ramp on my branch (very simple)
2) Add support 4D display in original Marlin (takes a long time)

description.text:
Old technique in new design printed with new technology.
Stirring the fantasy ~:D~
Designed in 3D Game Studio, converted into 3DS files and with Adobe CC student version made into solid STL files

UPDATE 05-Oct
Couple of requests to have it fit the phone without the any case on (for the brave), now added - see files.
--
Clips the Noise Cancelling battery pack to the back of your iPhone
designed to fit the Genuine Apple phone case; Or any other case that makes the back of the phone 62mm wide and 10mm thick
The wire wont get pulled and it makes it super easy to pocket the phone while the headphones are attached.
This is a re-mix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:185446 by lapostel, not intentionally, but when I seen theirs on here, the similarities were too close to be ignored - so re-mix it is :)
There are two versions, one with a wire clip to run the headphone wire alongside the battery(Bose_Phone_Clip2.stl) and one without.(Bose_Phone_Clip.stl)

I printed mine without any additional supports fairly slowly, although a brim support may allow faster speeds. Not 100% necessary.
I suppose if you wanted just one big clip rather than two little ones, you can just scale along Z-axis to the desired height.
These settings worked well for me.
0.4mm Nozzle
0.1mm Layer Height
0.4mm Wall
100% Infill
50mm/s Travel
120mm/s Fast Travel
Printed on Ultimaker Original
If you print one, please let me know how it went for you. This is only my 3rd design and maybe 10th print ever. :D

description.text: I love art and I hate seeing my bedroom walls all empty so I decided to make an original piece of art to decorate them. I have always been inspired by elements so I wanted to make a medallion that had the four elements on it. I also wanted to include some of my favorite animals on the art piece so I included a lion, a wolf, an eagle and an elephant. I also wanted to have a frame so I added four squares that bordered the medallion and gave it an illusion of a frame.

In order to make this art piece, all you have to do is design a circle and decorate the inside with the four elements. The actual designs have to be rastered onto the cirlce but the rest of the circle can be vector cut out. Next you have to simply make four more smaller cirlces and live trace the images of four different animals. After that, you have to design the four squares with any pattern that you want and print them out. Finally print the art pieces using wood and a laser cutter. Next you have to use wood glue and glue the four animal circles onto the actual medallion. Then using double sided tape of any kind or removable mounting tape just tape the pieces onto an empty wall.

It's a simple bumper for the Voice Recognition v2 Module. Inspired by this arduino bumper: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27759
Print and place the voice recognition module inside it.
Pulley for T2.5 Belt Mendel Prusa. Fits a standard 608ZZ (Roler Skate) bearing. BIG IMPROVEMENT IN PRINT QUALITY!

Print the Pulley, using less than 0.25 mm per layer. Adjust the speed a bit down. Part should print in about 22 minutes at 60mm/sec. The underside (not visible in the STL file) has lips to snap in the 608ZZ bearing.
With the ball bearings on the T2.5 belt, its a bit like having square wheels, exaggerated. The belt on the bearing causes a small sinus like movement. But you have to multiply that because both the x and the y axis are running on belts/bearings. This pulley has the same teeth as the belt and makes the printer run much smoother. You can see this in the print result. Far less "moire" in the print. Besides this you save bearing, only 3 needed instead of 6.

From a video game idea I came up with, I decided to model one of the machines used for travel.

Good news! I successfully printed the wingless version in one piece, using the STL file that excludes the wings. I had to use rafting and support in order to print it out, with full support. I think that the winged version would probably print successfully with the same printing specifications as the wingless version, only because of time constraints I couldn't test it out. Also, a couple of places are very fragile, such as the horns (one of which broke off almost immediately), and the "wrists" of the front legs. However, as a small desktop statue, I think my model will work perfectly fine. You might need to cut the platform it prints on.

I couldn't find a suitable cable clamp for my project, so I made one. Allows to attach a cable to a frame with 2 screws. Fully parametric design, you can easily change the size of the clamp, the diameter of the cable and of the screws. There are two clamp types :
1) Half-clamp (blue) : two clamps can be attached together to prevent the cable from going through a hole.
2) Full-clamp (yellow) : a single clamp can be used, screwed to a flat surface, to hold a cable. Both types can be generated from the same OpenSCAD file. This is my first published design, comments welcome.

description.header:
RELEASE 21/12/2012
v1.0 : Initial release (half-clamp only)
UPDATED 24/12/2012
v1.1: Now you can make a half-clamp or a full-clamp from a single OpenSCAD file !
UPDATED 25/12/2012
v1.2 : Now with rounded corners !
description.text:
Use OpenSCAD to open the cable_clamp.scad file.
Change the settings at the top of the file :
cable_diam is the cable diameter
screw_diam is the screw diameter You can also change cube_z and cable_press to change the clamp type between half- and full-clamp (see instructions in OpenSCAD file), and how much the cable is pressed (depending of the rigidity of the cable). Then, compile the design, and export an STL file. There are a few other parameters that allow you to change the size of the clamp, but default parameters should be fine for most uses. Try them out ! I did not make STL files because I don't know the size of the cables and screws you want to use.

description.text: Camera Deck mod for the Hovership MHQ to accommodate the KK 2.1.5 flight controller.  STL file titled "new cam deck v3" has a tiny mod, a small cutout to allow for easy access to the plug for the low voltage warning buzzer.  i originally just cut it out on my prototype with a forstner drill bit, but if you're making a new one you might as well just print it that way...

Modified the original MHQ camera deck to include a port large enough to see the KK 2.1.5 screen and buttons.  not elegant but works.  The gap is small enough that a 1300 or 1500 snappy lipo can bridge the opening. Extra thickness around the KK opening faces down and keeps the deck stiff.  Recommend using silicone "screws" to mount the KK board instead of the nylon standoffs, provides vibration dampening and allows for more "headroom" on the connectors.

description.text:
This allow you to place a 6cm diameter halo light underneath the printer so you can see your 3D prints in more detail. This works for the Printrbot Simple 2014 model, but it might work for others. You need supports and it will be hard to remove them, so what I did was I used a dremel to get rid of the supports.
This is where I got the Halo LED Light:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/1Pair-60mm-1210-3528-15LED-Car-Angel-Eyes-Halo-Ring-Light-Headlight-White-Light-/301212933623?pt=Motors_Car_Truck_Parts_Accessories&hash=item4621b09df7&vxp=mtr
There is a problem with the printer drawing up too much power
causing the light to flicker, but if you make one of these adjustable voltage regulators (or even buy them on line) you can set the brightness of your printer light.
http://www.robotshop.com/en/pololu-s8v3a-step-up-step-down-voltage-regulator.html

-Print the Model
-Clean up all of the supports
-Place the light holder on the printer (Shown in picture)
-Use a zip tie to hold the Halo light (Shown in picture)
-Connect the positive end into the red end of the 12v powersource (Show in picture)
-Connect the negative end into the black end of the 12v powersource (Show in picture)
-[there is a small place where you can insert the wires into the printer motherboard. You may need players to push them in]
-Turn on the printer and now you have light

title: Mobile Raspberry Computer Case - Portable Raspberry Pi-to-Go

description.text:
Everyone has seen Raspberry Pi Computer, the credit card sized mini PC circuit board that cost only $35. Now there is a new Mobile Raspberry Pi called Pi-to-Go. Mini LCD, 10 hour battery, and 64GB SSD hard drive. You can 3D print your own case and build your own. Complete instruction on how to build this Pi-to-go computer can be found here: http://blog.parts-people.com/2012/12/20/mobile-raspberry-pi-computer-build-your-own-portable-rpi-to-go/
Video of it in action
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E89s2h9swIc

Building this Raspberry Pi-to-go is not for everyone. Wiring all the electronics together does require some basic soldering and knowledge of basic wiring. Lets get started.
Step 1: Print all pieces.
Step 2: Snap screen portion to the base portion.
Step 3: Snap on right side cover

title: USB Base for Translucent Snowflake Ornament

description.text: This is a base for the Translucent Snowflake Ornament thing by pmoews.  It's desinged to use a USB cable to power an LED to light up the ornament from the inside.

• Print out the base.

  • Cut the device end off a USB cable. Strip the outer insulation and shield back about an inch.

  • Seperate out the four wires. Strip the ends of the red and black wires.

  • Cut the other two wires back to about a quarter inch, but don't strip them.

  • Push the cable thru the hole in the base, just to the point where you stripped the outer insulation. Fold back the two short wires, one to either side and use hot glue to hold the cable in place.

  • Take an LED of your choosing and sand the outside of it till it's all frosted looking. This will make the light from the LED more diffuse and prevent it from just lighting the top of the ornament.

  • Take the LED and an apropreate resistor to let the LED run off five volts. Cut the positive lead of the LED (The longer one) down to about a quarter inch and solder the resistor to it. Solder the red wire to the resistor.

  • Solder the black wire to the end of the other LED lead.

  • Use hot glue to hold the LED in place in the middle of the base. I found that having it stick up abut an inch from the base bottom helped.

  • Use a bit of glue to attach the ornament.

  • Plug into a nearby USB port and enjoy!

After seeing an Instructable on how to hand craft a batarang from the video game Arkham Asylum (http://www.instructables.com/id/Batarang-from-Arkham-Asylum-Game/), I realized that I could print one almost as large and definitely quicker than I could construct one from plexi. So here is a (partially) foldable batarang. Note - use of the batarang will not give you crime fighting powers nor is it likely to return to you after flinging it (although it did spin nicely).

I made this using Rhino3D 4.0, basically recreating the shapes posted on the instructable by creating a heightfiled (displacement map) and getting the contour lines, then using a loft between two similar curves  to get the edge rather than having to cut a bevel. For some reason the holes in the mesh didn't print (even though they look fine - something weird about how Rhino handles mesh holes), so I just drilled them out, used a spare 3/16 machine screw, nut and two washers for the central pivot (which doesn't pivot very far) and partially drilled two 1/4" holes for 2 1/4" rare earth magnet thats fit flat into the wings at this depth.

comments.text: Forgot to mention - epoxy the back piece to the fixed piece., then drill the hole through the pivot piece and the back piece (everything aligns easily by shape), as in the Instructable.

author: 3dprintedrobot

description.text:
Print the razor blade into the handle!  
With Emmett's Razor Scraper I found that the scraper lasted about as long as the razor blades did, so I decided that in order to make a more secure holder that I would embed the blade in the plastic. These have proved incredibly useful for me considering that razor blades and PLA are both so cheap.

Make sure that the build matches the type of razor blade you have. Mine has a rounded anchor in the middle that I used to make this more secure. I sliced with WHPThomas's 200µ print settings, but I had 5 shells to make the anchor as strong as possible, 20% inf.
When the print starts do a Pause @ ZPos: 2mm. Then when the print pauses take the razor blade and test fit it into the print. Mine took a little finagling. Once in place, remove it, put some superglue on the plastic closest to the handle to hold the blade in extra strong. Replace the razor blade and push for a good stick. Unpause the print and enjoy! Worked like a charm for me and I use them to remove prints from the build plate.

author: HSU

description.text:
Reductor that done from identical gears 1:4 each (uniform) and can be setup with as many gears in sequence as you need (scalable) to get ratio and torque that you need.
On images reductor done from 4 gears and has ration 1:256, but you can easy install more/less gears to each of two reductor axes to have ratio that you need.
There also included fram for gears system with holder for motor.

Print as many gears 1:4 as you need (file "Gear 10-to-40.STL"). Then print 1 (or two if you want to make it symmetrical) detail "Motor Holder (Opposite).STL" - this will makes frame (you can also adjust and print detail "Motor Holder (Top).STL" as opposite side of frame). Use bolts M4 to connect frames with gears inside. First gear put just on frame, before putting second gear print detail "Motor Holder (Rail) 7 mm.STL" and install it on bolt M4 first (it will makes correct shift in height before second gear). Then put all other gears you want and finally put one more detail "Motor Holder (Rail) 7 mm.STL".
Frame has 3 holes to connect frame parts outside gears axes - print 3 details "Motor Holder (Rail) 37 mm.STL" (for 4 gears 37 mm will be just fine, if you use other number of gears you can adjust height in file "Motor Holder (Rail).SLDPRT" taking in mind that every gear is 12 mm height) and install them into remaining 3 holes of frame.
I also attached sample holder for motor that I have (28 mm diameter) and adapter that makes possible install first gear with 12 tooth (small one on images). Probably you'll need to adjust those details according to motor you have (you can do it in files "Motor Holder (Top).SLDPRT", "Motor Gear Connector (Sliced) - 2.SLDPRT" and "Metric - Spur gear 2M 12T 20PA 12FW ---S12N75H50L5N.sldprt"). I also attached sample small gear with 10 tooths (file "Metric - Spur gear 2M 10T 20PA 7FW ---S10N75H50L5N.stl").
Note: if you want to print directly from .STL file you'll need to flip Y-Z planes for some details to place them correct on printing table. 
Good luck ;)

comments.text: I realize that this has been posted almost 5 years ago.  So I am asking, have you made any improvements?  Anything that you would have changed? Have you done any reliability testing to see how durable this setup is?
comments.author: Bugeyz

comments.text: The way you have some of these parts oriented would be unprintable. Remember that just because you might use a host software that can flip them the correct way, not everyone does. Maybe you could rotate them so they print in the proper orientation so every person interested doesn't have to post-process in order to get them to work?
comments.author: thantik

comments.text: thantik: This read very often, in my opinion, a man who can not orient himself before printing model, has nothing to do with the printer, it is an embarrassment and should consider something else. If you do not print the way it is oriented, let's fuck and fuck with, noob.

That's the wrong attitude that this community needs.  Also a lot of people use things like Pronterface on a minimum spec netbook.  Flipping, rotating, etc would require another piece of software.  It's better just to properly orient your parts before uploading them.  If 10,000 people download and print your design, and you save them 30 seconds each, you've just saved 83 hours of lost time.
comments.author: Proksis

2 color model of a necklace for Burning Man 2014.
Print, drill 2 holes in the ends, and connect your chain or cord, tie a knot and stick it around your neck!
I was having trouble getting the holes to look nice, thus the drilling step...

Steps used to create this:
1) Record audio
2) Capture image of audio waveform, blur it, and use levels to get it to look nice.
3) Create mesh in Blender, add displace modifier, use image from step #2.
4) Fiddle with shapes & booleans to make necklace shape, subtract the audio "mountains" from the necklace.
5) Create text, convert to mesh, subtract from bottom of necklace (flipping around so it reads right)
If you'd like more detailed instructions, I can make a video to show all the steps I took.

description.text: Every time I teach a class, I end up with these little do-dad 3D sketches.  I figure someone may want to use them for something.  Some of these are a little strange.

A model of a 2 speed capstan. Once again planetary gears are involved. I'm surprised how ubiquitous they seem to be.
The output ie that which the rope to be hauled is wrapped around, is represented by the planet carrier.
For high speed winding disengage the pawl and wind in a clockwise direction. Engage the pawl and the speed goes down and the torque goes up.
Or, to get a pleasing clicking sound from the pawl and high speed (reversed) winding, turn in a counter clockwise direction.
Short video here: http://youtu.be/yJSMlenLgec
Designed in MOI, made in Diamond Age PLA on and Ultimaker 1

It's a while since I made this but I don't recall any special requirements. I normally use 1.2mm walls, 20% fill and 0.2mm layer heights at 200C.
I used Diamond Age PLA.
Do take care with orientation in your slicer as some parts are sure to need laying down or turning upside down.
I have a box of springs and one fitted nicely but a rubber band woud do just a well.

title: Mini Kossel Springform Glass Mounting Tabs

description.text:
Meant for mounting 220mm Springform glass base from http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0000VLYQI in standard 240mm Misumi 1515 Mini Kossel. Remixed from https://github.com/ianlee74/3dPrinterParts/tree/master/Kossel%20Glass%20Mounts
I had difficulty printing the tabs as is and had to add the brim to avoid curling. *** It's been pointed out that the mounting holes are slightly off. comments.text: Hi, unfortunately I don't have the original design file and my only modification was adding the brim to the part using openSCAD to enable it to print better. I had the same problem too and ended up filling the gap with ABS glue and centered the plate before letting it dry. If I figure out how to move the hole, I will update this design, but the ABS glue is working well so far. The plate does not move during calibration or printing, and is easy to remove for cleanup.
comments.author: bzboi

comments.text: Just an update on this. I bought a second identical springform and guess what?!? It's smaller than the first one! It looks like there's quite a bit of tolerance in the glass diameter, which could explain the many springform reviews complaining about leaks. I'm guessing that if you're trying to fit this on the standard 240mm 1515 frame the ABS glue would be needed on a case by case basis, and it could be challenging to buy two springforms and expect to switch out build plates. If anyone finds a better springform that has consistent diameter, please let me know!

description.text: this is a playmobil sword i made for my younger siblings
i used Google sketchup

Using the die that Shiera made, I extended it to print the die in one color and the pips in the other on a dual extruder machine. 
You need two extruders and one model for each. 
One model is just the die; that one will print alone. The other is the pips, floating in air. Don't try to print that by itself.
When combined, the printer should print one extruder for one model and one for the other.

You need a dual extruder machine such as the Replicator Dual.
Note: this is for ReplicatorG; your software make work differently.
This is cribbed from http://www.makerbot.com/support/replicatorg/documentation/dualstrusion/)
1) Download the two models (or use the scad file to generate new ones).
2) In ReplicatorG, go to Gcode and select "merge stl for dual extrusion"
3) There are 3 fields. Put D6Diepips15.stl in one field and D6Die15.stl in the other. In the third, type the resulting file you want. Like "dualdie.gcode".
4) Click merge and 2 windows pop up.
5) Set the settings in each window. Be sure to set "use default start and end" and "use print-o-matic" and turn OFF rafts.
6) Click "generate gcode" on both windows.
7) It will take a long time but the result will be in the filename you selected.
8) Print that file!

description.text:
This is an alternative spool mount for the Makerbot Replicator 1 (for wider spools with smaller holes). Just yesterday I visited the http://www.protospace.nl fablab in Utrecht (Netherlands). And they had a lot of Ultimaker printers working with PLA. And well... the air was a LOT fresher than in my studio when I print with ABS. Since I already had a roll of PLA, I decided I wanted to give that a go. Sadly.. the roll was a different size than the ones from Makerbot. So I figured I'd use some of the ABS I still had mounted to create a new mount. This mount is much thinner than the original ones on my Makerbot Replicator 1.
It works with rolls that have a hole diameter of 3 centimeters (1.18inch)
And the roll has to be 9cm thick (3.54inch) I included my Blender 3D file so it's easy to modify the source to fit whatever roll you need. I printed it in two halves and there are some small holes in the design to attach the halves using tie-wraps.
Print both parts, then attach them using 2 small tie-wraps.

description.text:
All parts - Creator KIT - 3D printer
Creator aims to promote the creation, putting technology, talent and vision at the disposal of its customers, to innovate by 3D print.

This coupler clamps directly to the lead screw, while also clamping to the motor via a rubber tube slipped over the shaft. This gives some tolerance to misalignment or bent screws without causing Z position errors like a springy helical coupler. It's just a tweak of Triffid Hunter's great iteration; in previous generations of the part, the clamping screws conflicted with the rubber tubing if the lead screw was smaller than the tubing O.D. This just locates the clamp screws relative to the larger of the tubing OD or the lead screw diameter, thus working with narrower screws (such as my 6.35mm ones) or thicker-walled tubing.

Update: there was a missing semicolon in the original SCAD. It's fixed now. 
Mine worked sweetly just as printed from the STL. If you have .250" (6.35mm) lead screws, chances are your local hardware store has inch size tubing, like mine. I used 1/4" O.D. x 0.170" I.D. vinyl tube which measured almost exactly 7 mm when snugly stretched the motor shaft.
Triffid Hunter suggests printing with 90% infill. I used PLA.
This really improved my bottom layers (and therefore prints) by making my Z zeroing repeatable. My cheap, easily bent lead screws are now a lot more tolerable.

remixed_from.author: sphynx
remixed_from.title: Spiral vase/tea light with helixes of sinusoidal cubes

description.text: A vase made up of three interwoven spirals of polyhedrons.

This is a set of vases that have three spirals of polyhedra wrapped around them. The spirals come in right-hand and left-hand forms and the vase comes in 3 variations: 1) - spiral polyhedron vase. This is three spirals of polyhedra added to a cylinder.
2) - spiral polyhedron vase core. This is three spirals of polyhedra subtracted from a cylinder.
3) - spiral polyhedron vase gear. This is the core, but stretched out so that it meshes with the surface of 1). If you print 1 right-hand and 3 left-hand (or vice-versa) the two vases from interlocking gears. Very nice to play with. So there are a total of 2 x 3 = 6 possible vases. Print with no fill and no top. Prints out great on my Ultimaker even at high print speeds (100mm/s) because there are no nasty overhangs, sharp curves etc. I printed with an 0.8mm wall thickness. 0.4 would also be OK, but the vases would not be as strong.

author: ArchieMagat

title: Magnetic plate for ring of LED's ("Angel Eyes") for Rostock Max V2 (Should work with V1 too)

description.text: This is a plate for securing 60mm "angel eyes" to the Rostock Max effector.  I have mine ziptied to the plate, but you could also glue it in place I suppose.  I initially created a plate with clips that secured the angel eyes, but it was just problematic.
Glue 10mm neodymium magnets in the sockets, zip tie or glue angel eyes to the plate.  The magnets attach to the screws that secure the hotend bracket.

comments.text: Should the 3 magnet holders fit inside the rings around the screws, or does it just sit on top?  It seems too big as-is to fit inside.
comments.author: mattster98

comments.text: And now my magnets don't seem to want to stick to the screws.  Back to the drawing board.
comments.author: mattster98

This Thing is a MakerBot 3D Portrait of Robert Fox scanned at the MakerBot Retail Store in SoHo on Dec 21, 2012.  These scans are at 1/4th the original size.

• Preview each model by clicking the thumbnail on the top left. Click on the cube to see the model in 3D.
  • Download the STL of the file you would like to print. The first thumbnail corresponds to portrait_1, and so on.
  • Open the STL in MakerWare or ReplicatorG, resize as necessary and print.
